text: The roar of some terrifying creature. We are close to the BOY, age twelve, racing through the snowy dark. He is terrified. He manages to glance back behind him. In a shaky dark swirl we catch glimpses of what appear to animals, black against the blue snow, chasing after him. glimpse of light their eyes flash, revealing TWO WOLVES - tearing through the moonlit woods. The boy tries desperately to pick up speed, dodging falle limbs and rocks along his way. Strangely, he’s barefoot, thin tank-top and pajama bottoms, running through a dark, eerie landscape. Up ahead he sees a way to veer off from the path and dip along an incline. He takes the turn, tearing through brus he descends along the side of a hill into a slight recess hoping to drop out of sight. Through the black mesh of trees he spots the wolves runni past. In relief, he exhales loudly, catching his breath. he pulls himself up. He turns - and gasps. The two wolves have reverted course and are racing right towards him. Startled, he loses his footing, and stumbles the ground. His foot is tangled in some roots. He starts yanking with all his might, glancing up to see: The wolves are galloping toward him. Their sharp teeth gl in the moonlight. We see the boy from the wolves’ point o view. The boy’s eyes flash with terror as we close in on him. There’s nothing he can do. In the distance someone is cal a name...”"Ben...Ben...Ben...” We hear the boy’s SCREAM.  WONDERSTRUCK 2. INT. ROBBY’S BEDROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 2 BEN - the boy in the dream, a thoughtful, sullen kid - bo up in bed. His face is covered in sweat. From across the we hear his cousin ROBBY.
Ben!!

(panting, still lost in the dream) What? Ben, tangled in the sheets of a fold-up cot, is wearing t same T-shirt and pajama bottoms he was wearing in the dre Robby, 14-years-old, with the beginning of a mustache, switches on his lamp, knocking two hunting magazines to t floor. He is sweating too and whips the blanket off him.
What? What’s the matter? Huh? Can’t you hear me? Are you deaf?
Stop it, Robby. There is a knock from the other side of the wall.
Go to sleep, boys!
(returning the call) Sorry, mom.
Sorry, Aunt Jenny!

(without taking his eyes off of Ben) Shut. Up. Robby makes a gun with his fingers and shoots it toward B then switches off his lamp and turns over in his bed. We can hear the crickets for the first time.

Ben eyes Robby’s side of the room, his collection of guns knives, fishing rods and hunting trophies.  WONDERSTRUCK 3. He turns over to face the wall. A small slip of blue pape tacked there. In the moonlight it reads: We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars. He glides his fingers across the words before reaching un his pillow to pull out a leather wallet. It has stitching around the edges and the silhouette of a wolf stamped ont the front. Ben covers the wolf with his hand, opens the wallet and p out a folded piece of paper. It’s a newspaper item that reads: February 18th, 1977, Local Librarian Dies In Auto Accident A distant tug of MUSIC stirs up a few fleeting images:
Black shoes. Old people taking their seats in the pews fo the funeral. A tear skidding down a woman’s cheek. A photograph of the woman who died, classmates sitting seve rows back with their parents.

An egret is being drawn in ballpoint pen in a spiral notebook. It sits perched on a branch behind which a crosshatch predator looms, a wolf or hound. We see Ben hunched over his notebook, trying to get it ju right. Three boys Ben’s age stare at him. Ben looks away from them as a yellow Gunflint bus pulls u INT. ROBBY’S BEDROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 5 Ben shakes himself out of the memory and looks again at t newspaper clipping. There’s a photograph of a pretty young woman with a ponyt the same woman in the photograph at the funeral in the flashback. Words and phrases from the article jump out at Ben: Elain Wilson... ice... lost control... darkness... survived by son, Benjamin

FLASHBACK - INT. BEN’S BEDROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 6 There’s a small knock on Ben’s bedroom door. Ben, in bed, looks up from a book on constellations. His mom, the woma from the photographs, sticks her head in the room. She ha her hair in a ponytail and is wearing her favorite robe.
Hey, guess what? We forgot a present. She holds up a small wrapped gift. Ben keeps reading.
What's that?
Constellations.

Catch. She tosses Ben the gift, but it bounces off the bed and f to the floor. He sighs and goes to pick it up. A telescop with a bow on it is set up beside him, near his window. His mom approaches, picking up some cellophane, a small r and a model of a whale, which she places atop his shelf.

You really do live in a museum. Ben’s shelf is in fact his own natural history museum: ro and pebbles and shells, bones and fossils, all organized groups, with hand-written explanatory cards. She turns ba to Ben, who is opening his last present.

Why do you always look so sad, Benjamin Wilson? Ben ignores the remark, a practice he has recently and selectively adopted. She takes a glance through the new telescope as he opens up a small box. It’s the wolf wallet, brand new.
Neat. Like the one we saw, on the trail. Thanks, mom. Elaine looks up from the telescope and smiles.  WONDERSTRUCK 5.
Sure, handsome.
So...
Yes?

Was my dad an astronomer? Elaine's expression immediately changes, as if a curtain come down. Ben senses this but keeps talking, aware he’s dangerous cliff. BEN (CONT’D) Maybe that’s why I like outer space so much. It makes sense... His mom, with a forced smile, walks silently over and sit the edge of his bed.
Happy birthday, Mister twelve-year old. She gently kisses his forehead.
Don’t stay up too long. She exits the room, leaving Ben awake in bed, frustrated.

Ben approaches his mom’s bedroom from the upstairs landin passing a bookshelf stuffed with old toys and science projects. Through her partly opened door he sees her smoking a cigarette while standing beside an old portable record player. She pulls her pony tail tighter, and walks to an alcove where she has a desk. She sits. David Bowie’s “Spa Oddity” has begun to play. Ben settles at the bedroom door as his mother closes her for a moment, listening to the music.
(quietly) Mom?  WONDERSTRUCK 6. Elaine doesn’t hear him. BEN (CONT’D) (louder) Mom? Elaine jumps.
Jesus - God, you scared me. What are you doing out of bed?
(taking a deep breath) Why won’t you ever talk about him? Other kids know their dads...
Not now, Ben. Go back to bed.
It’s what I wished for, you know, when I blew out the candles.
Another time, okay? When it’s the right time.

It’s never the right time. Ben turns to his mother’s mirror, which is covered in postcards of famous works of art, clippings, and some of childhood artwork. Stuck on top with a piece of tape is the small blue piece paper with the words: We are all in the gutter, but some us are looking at the stars.
What does this mean?
What Ben?
This quote - “We are all in the gutter but some of us are looking at the stars.” You said it the night we saw the shooting stars, and now it’s on your wall. What does it mean?  10 WONDERSTRUCK 7.
(taking a deep breath, wishing he’d go back to sleep) What do you think it means?

(disappointed, almost to himself) That’s what you always say. INT. ROBBY’S ROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 8 Ben, back in the cot of his cousin’s room, is looking at quote on the wall, gently tracing its edges. We FOLLOW each word as he whispers them to himself:
We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars... The last word: “stars” fills his vision and ours, as a so swirl of MUSIC RISES...

text: A GALAXY OF STARS which we slowly glide out from.
THE EYES OF A YOUNG GIRL, staring up at something, a movi screen perhaps.

We float out from on the word: Stars (white on black) but in fancy letters to reveal... A 1920's fan magazine, the full headline: Our Brightest Stars.  11 12 WONDERSTRUCK 8. The featured actress is LILLIAN MAYHEW, a silent screen s with large eyes, a tiny mouth and long hair. A girl's hand caresses the page. Then - RIP! We see ROSE, a twelve-year-old girl, tear the page out of magazine. Long blonde hair, a simple light dress. Intense determined. Sad. The SHOPKEEPER, hearing the noise, looks up, spots Rose a starts yelling (though we do not hear any sounds). A mother and daughter shopping nearby turn to look at the commotion. Rose, with the torn page in her hand, runs past the mothe and daughter, out of the store. The mother pulls her daug closer, as if out of danger. The shopkeeper yells after Rose as she runs off down the street. What a strange little girl...

Rose is now hurrying to a small clearing at the rocky edg the Hudson river. She rushes to retrieve paper and pencil from her bag, wit the urgent need to express herself, even in her solitude. With a shaking hand she writes across the paper: HELP ME!

She then begins to fold up the piece of paper. She tucks and folds the paper until she’s made...a little boat. She sets the boat onto the surface of the river. She watches it as it floats precariously off towards Manhattan - and the Fates.

We see and hear boats knocking against each other in the water.  13 14 15 WONDERSTRUCK 9. INT. ROBBY’S BEDROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 13 Ben lies awake in bed, listening to the sound of the boat He sees something out the window. Ben wiggles out of bed and grabs a red flashlight from hi cousin Robby’s shelf.

Ben walks out of his aunt’s house along a small path lead to the house next door. The house looks very much like hi aunt’s house, though it seems to have been abandoned. But what’s drawn Ben is the strange, inexplicable fact that a light has been turned on from inside the second floor, th only interior light burning at this hour. As we will soon learn, this is the house Ben and his moth lived in, that Ben grew up in, until his mother died sudd and nothing in his life would ever be the same. Ben walks silently past the knocking boats on his way tow the lit windows of his old house. On the way he also pass small cabin that appears to have been shuttered for some time. Leaves crunch underfoot as Ben nears his old house, approaching from the rear. He stops a moment when he sees back door is open. He thinks he hears something buzzing f within. A voice? He continues approaching, quietly. EXT./INT. BEN’S HOUSE - 1977 - NIGHT 15 He realizes how loudly he’s breathing and stops for a mom suddenly understanding: it’s a record playing inside - th song “Space Oddity.” He switches on his flashlight and continues slowly into t house. It all feels very spooky, like some sort of frozen memory. Most of the furniture is stacked or covered, standing bes piles of sealed-up boxes and kitchenware still stacked on counters, as if someone had begun to pack up the house bu never got around to finishing it. Ben walks up the stairs.  16 17 WONDERSTRUCK 10. INT. BEN’S HOUSE - HALLWAY - 1977 - NIGHT 16 Ben’s heart is pounding as he slowly walks down the hallw past his old room, towards the source of the light, and t music: his mother’s door. It’s open slightly. He’s about to give it a shove when - A shadow moves across the floor. He stops. He smells something, the smoke from her cigarettes... Through the crack in the doorway he sees something unbelievable...a blonde woman with a ponytail wearing his mother’s favorite robe. Ben’s hand is trembling.
(terrified) Mom? Are you... He pushes open the door.

INT. ROSE’S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER - 1927 - DAY 17 Rose is clearing the surface of her cluttered desk with o swipe. She is carefully loading a brush full of rubber ce onto the back of her clipping, coating the edges. She is carefully placing it in a large bound scrapbook and press down the corners. We can make out part of what it says as blows on it to dry: Will our brightest star turn out to be a permanent fixtur the heavens, or will she be a comet, who burns brightly f brief moment and then vanishes? She returns a toppled post-card from its place on her win sill. The card reads: Feb., 1927 - Happy Birthday, Rose, Walter and is addressed to: Miss Rose Kincaid, 168 River Street, Hoboken NJ. Mostly dry, Rose begins to flip back through the pages. W see the articles and ephemera Rose has collected, the dat moving backwards through time as she flips from back to front: Is Lillian’s Career Over?  18 WONDERSTRUCK 11. SCANDAL! A Divorce In Hollywood! Mayhew Shocker! - Movie Star Journeys With Young Actor There’s a small advertisement for a movie: FORBIDDEN LOVE, Starring Lillian Mayhew Lillian Mayhew’s Seventh Hit Picture In A Row Young Actress Marries Doctor Lillian Mayhew Is Engaged Mayhew Glows in Debut - A New Star On The Horizon? Rose closes the scrapbook and gazes out her window a mome in thought. Out the window, through a break in the trees, is a piece the Manhattan skyline that Rose has stared at every day o her life. As we DRIFT back into Rose’s room, past her lace curtains across her shelves of books, we find that she too has a t world on display on the shelves of her room, but hers is hand-made skyline. Countless buildings she has made from newsprint and magazine and paper line her shelves as if t city she longs for across the water has tumbled into her room.

INT. BEN’S HOUSE - 1977 - NIGHT 18 Light spills onto Ben’s darkened face as he stares into h mother’s old room - His MOTHER, like a ghost, with her back to him, is dancin the music. She is smoking a cigarette. She nonchalantly reaches up to pull her pony tail tighter. Ben drops his flashlight and gasps. His mom turns. But it’s not his mom! It’s his cousin JANET, a teenage gi with big glasses.
(startled) Ben!  WONDERSTRUCK 12.
Janet!
What are you doing here?
No! What are you doing here? This isn’t your house! Those aren’t your clothes! You... He wipes his eyes, feeling stupid and angry for having thought it might actually have been his mom.
(to herself, mortified) I knew I shouldn’t have turned on the light. Benji, I...
You smoke? She looks down at her hand, as if noticing the cigarette the first time, and quickly stubs it out.
No! I mean... Oh god, please don’t tell my parents! They’1l kill me.
I don’t understand! You’re wearing my mom’s clothes!
Benji, I’m so sorry. This was supposed to be my secret place - I just needed - somewhere -
(turning) I can’t look at you like that! Ben backs up into the record player. The arm skips across record making a terrible noise.
You okay?
Yes. I’m fine.
Benji?
Ben turns away.

I’m sorry. Ben sits on the bed. Janet slips off the robe she’d put on (the same one his mother wore in his birthday memory). Beneath it Janet is wearing cut-off jeans and a tank top. Ben watches as she dutifully puts the record back in its 13. sleeve, adjusting her glasses and pulling out her ponytai A pause.
Are your parents going to sell this house?
I've heard them talking about it.
Why can’t I just move back in? It’s my house.
I know. And Robby's kind of a pest.
If I knew where my dad was...I could just... She watches him a moment.
You still having those nightmares?
Not... Sometimes. Janet isn’t sure she’s making him feel any better and sta collecting her things.
Come on. We should go home probably.
I am home.
I know... I meant-  19 WONDERSTRUCK 14.
You go. I want to stay here a little longer.
I don’t know if that’s such a good idea. There’s supposed to be storms- Ben doesn’t move. He just stares straight ahead.
I won’t tell your parents.
What?
That you were smoking. Just let me stay a little longer.
You really won’t tell? Seriously?
I swear.
Oh my God. Then I completely owe you a favor, Benji. For real. Janet pauses a moment. Ben looks up at her then back down
(gently) We all miss her, you know. Ben furrows his brow.
Don’t stay too long, okay?
MUSIC. Rose approaches a bustling downtown block. In the center of it all is a cinema. The marquee reads: Lillian Mayhew in DAUGHTER OF THE STOR  20 21 22 WONDERSTRUCK 15.
MUSIC hushes as Rose slips into the darkening theater and takes her seat. Curtains gather as an ORGANIST, a balding man with strang tufts of hair, takes his seat. The lights go down.
The flickering light of a projector almost blinds us. From the first pre-credit logo for Artcraft Pictures, Ros transported.

TITLE CARD: Starring Lillian Mayhew Rose's face lights up at the name on screen. ON SCREEN: the silent film IRISES UP on a hillside covere tall grass. The wind is blowing fiercely and a storm is coming in. The rain picks up as two dying trees are rattl in the wind. Into this scene comes LILLIAN MAYHEW as the terrified You Mother, carrying her baby in a blanket. CLOSE-UP of Young Mother, her eyes wide, the baby asleep her arms. TITLE CARD: “Oh no! The storm has arrived!” ON SCREEN: a shriek of organ over a flash of lightning (silent movie style.) Rose stares up at the screen. The Young Mother sees a small cabin in the distance.

INT. BEN’S HOUSE - 1977 - NIGHT 22 Ben looks around the room, not sure what to do with his sudden liberty.  WONDERSTRUCK 16. He opens up a drawer and examines its contents, and then next. At first it’s embarrassing, seeing his mother’s pri intimate things, but soon he finds himself opening every of her drawers as if unable to stop himself. In one, he finds an old coffee tin and lifts the plastic off of it. Inside he finds a wad of cash, a sort of rainy fund his mother must have kept hidden. He lifts out the w to see if there’s anything else in the tin before replaci it with the cash and lid back inside the drawer, and resu his meander. Then, in the bottom drawer, Ben spots something truly strange. Something wrapped in a brown paper bag that’s be wrapped up for a very long time. Just as Ben takes hold o in his hand - A boom of thunder crashes as Ben carefully unfolds the br paper bag and reaches inside. It’s a very old, blue book. On the back cover he reads: Published by The American Museum of Natural History, New York, New York He turns the book over. Its title stamped in faded black letters:
BANG - another crash of thunder makes Ben jump. He peers through the window. Another BOLT and FLASH throttle the room, sending the hou into sudden darkness.

(Whispering to himself) No no no no no! Ben tries the lamp. Nothing. He spots the red flashlight and switches it on. He moves the beam around the room, then settles back into bed. He waits a moment. In the quiet, he turns the flashl towards the book. He opens up the old blue book and reads the first passage
“A curator’s job is an important one, for it is the curator who decides what belongs in the museum. (MORE )
23 24 WONDERSTRUCK 17.

In a way, anyone who collects things in the privacy of his own home is a curator..." As Ben continues reading we begin to DRIFT... INT. BEN’S HOUSE - HALLWAY - BEDROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 23 WE FLOAT down the hallway, into Ben’s old room, to his ol collection of objects, left behind in the dark... as if t book were describing him. As his V.O. continues we survey his rows of shells and strangely shaped stones and teeth and tiny animal skulls, fossils, pinecones, leaves from local trees, all arranged with handwritten cards annotating every find...

“But how did the very first curators store their collections? They were kept in pieces of furniture called Cabinets of Wonder. Eventually, some collections grew beyond the confines of a single cabinet and took over entire rooms. See figure 9.” INT. BEN’S HOUSE - MOTHER’S BEDROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 24 Ben, still reading on his mother’s bed, turns the page to Figure 9. Lit by the red flashlight, the double-page spread feature ancient engraving of a CABINET OF WONDERS.

(Whispers) Oh...my god. We see what he sees...a cabinet, perhaps, but of such ext unfoldability it appears to consume an entire room, leavi little more than the edge of its checkerboard floor. The endless drawers and shelves, filled with strange and vari objects - stuffed reptiles, decapitated heads, dried fish skeleton insects, to name but a few - all unfold from an intricately carved central cabinet, crowned with a crest sea shells and coral. A giraffe’s head peeks up from one of the cabinet. Ben's finger moves across the drawing, as if trying to to everything in it. Then he turns the page.  25 26 WONDERSTRUCK 18. There, pressed against the spine of the book, is an old yellow bookmark. He pulls it out for examination. The old, dog-eared relic depicts a burnt-red sketch of a bookstore, beneath which is printed: Kincaid Books 165 We 73rd street, New York, New York, 10024. 212 623 0723 He turns it over. There, on the back, in black ink, someone has written: Elaine, I’ll wait for you. Love, Danny

TITLE CARD: “Where can we find shelter from the storm?” ON SCREEN: The Young Mother cradles a Baby in her arms. In a murky LONG SHOT, the Young Mother runs out from unde the sheltering trees into a wild forest, wracked by savag winds. Her hair whips and twists in the gale. In CLOSE UP, the Young Mother looks around desperately fo protection. She spots something: a cabin in the distance (shot in miniature...antique special effects). Her face brightens with hope and she begins to run toward the cabin. But the organ MUSIC blares as the wind picks up. And the miniature cabin trembles in the terrible gust, which pull off its roof and sweeps it away. Soon the rest of the hou shakes, buckles and falls down, pulled by tiny threads. The Young Mother screams and collapses in fright, coverin her Baby for protection, raising a single hand towards go In the audience, Rose watches the silent film intensely.

INT. BEN’S HOUSE - MOTHER’S ROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 26 Outside, pounding thunder and flashing lightning.  27 28 WONDERSTRUCK 19. The bookmark shakes in Ben’s fingers. He looks again at t words: Elaine, I’ll wait for you. Love, Danny

(to himself) Danny... Ben turns the bookmark over and scans the address at the bottom for the phone number of the bookstore. A powder-blue phone is sitting on the night stand, within reach. Ben picks up the receiver and holds it against his good e He dials the number printed on the bookmark. The storm gr Each number rolls slowly around the rotary dial - 8...7.. with each one Ben’s heart beats faster - 8...8...9...0 .. watches the dial pivot back around the final time.
He hears a click - then: A headbusting BOOM OF THUNDER and BOLT OF LIGHTNING that the house and sears the world with electric visions.

MUSIC peaks over A RAPID MONTAGE of audience faces, mouths open, eyes wide some with tears, lit by cinema light. Then blackness. FADE-UP TITLE CARD: The End (and below in smaller letters An Artcraft Pictures Production The curtains unfurl and the house lights rise. Rose wipes her eyes, all-too-quickly back to earth.

MUSIC hangs as the theater lets out and a large truck pul up out front. It has begun to rain. Umbrellas are opening Rose makes her way along the side of the truck, which rea Vitaphone Sound Company. It’s rear door swings open, near knocking her down.  29 30 WONDERSTRUCK 20. Workers stream past, setting a ramp, and starting to haul wood crates out of the truck and onto dolly’s. MUSIC darkens as a THEATER EMPLOYEE, up on a ladder, unfu a banner from the marquee which reads: This Cinema Will B Closed During Installation of Hoboken’s First SOUND SYSTE Experience 100% All Talking! See And HEAR Your Favorite Stars! Rose is reading: See And HEAR...
Suddenly stricken, rain pelting, MUSIC taunting - Rose tu and runs off the main street, as the skies open.

INT. BEN’S HOUSE - MOTHER’S ROOM - 1977 - NIGHT 29 Ben’s eyes flutter open. SILENCE. He finds himself lying on the floor of his mom’s room. Peaceful in the silence. The storm must have passed. But something's wrong. The blue receiver is lying on the floor out of reach, bla and smoldering. The old book he found, soft-cover blue, lies open behind face down on the ground. With a strange slowness Ben turns his head towards the window. He sees rain still falling, shaking the trees, an lightning still flashing from the sky... yet there is sti no sound. No sound at all.

DOCTORS rush an active gurney down a long white hall, connected to other life-sustaining equipment on wheels. NURSES lean in with anxious eyes, adjusting tubes, record figures. Fluorescent lights flash by overhead.  31 WONDERSTRUCK 21.

Ben’s face. His eyes wide open. He sits up suddenly. AUNT JENNY is sitting on the bed, dressed in her work uni (her name, “Jenny,” stitched into her brown blouse). She looks exhausted and scared, as Janet looks on beside her. Robby sits sulking in the corner. Aunt Jenny strokes Ben' hair and speaks to him, but we don’t hear any sound. Ben looks back, and tries to reply, but the sound of his voice has been replaced by a deeply buried echo.
Where am I? What happened? It sounds more like the memory of a voice than anything anyone could actually hear.

(Mouthing the words...) What’s wrong? Hello? Hello? Aunt Jenny puts a finger to her mouth, mouthing: “Shhh,” indicating that she can hear him. The nurse hands Jenny a clipboard with a piece of paper, a pen. Aunt Jenny writes something down. She shows what s written to Ben: It’s OK. You had an accident. Ben doesn’t understand. Jenny crosses out what she wrote. She turns the pad aroun Ben can see and draws a simple house - a box with a trian on top. She adds a curly telephone line and a stick figur holding the line to his ear.

She draws a storm cloud over the house, and a jagged lightning bolt coming out of the cloud, hitting the house Then she traces a line from the lightning bolt, through t house, through the telephone wire, into the stick figure’ head. Ben’s watches with wide, stricken eyes. BEN (CONT’D) (mouthing the words) I don’t remember.  32 33 WONDERSTRUCK 22. He grabs the pen and paper and writes: I can’t talk! Aunt Jenny writes back: Yes you can. You just can’t hear yourself. Then she underlines the word: yourself Ben, overwhelmed by everything, looks around helplessly a rests his head on the pillow. Jenny kisses his temple to to comfort him.
The storm has ended. Rose hurries in the front door of th house, soaked from the rain. She runs up the stairs to he room.

She shuts the door behind her and turns with a start when MUSIC striking - someone stamps their foot on the floor. her father, DOCTOR KINCAID, a large man in an expensive s who has been waiting for her in the corner of her room. H glaring. He stands, wagging his finger and scolding her in rage (i words we do not hear but can certainly imagine):

Look at you! Just LOOK at you! Do you have any idea what trouble and worry you inflict on this home? Do you?! How in God’s name do you continue to abuse the liberty I extend you - and throw it in my face? Why I have half a mind to... He remembers the note he wrote, which he thrusts out for ("Here - read!”): You are in serious trouble, young lady! Your teacher come tomorrow. Study his book! He shoves a large black book into Rose’s hands and storms of his daughter’s room, slamming the door behind him. Rose looks down at the large black book, reading its full title for the first time:

text: 34 35 36 WONDERSTRUCK 23. by Dr. T.M. Gill Rose crumples onto her bed, as if from its sheer weight. yanks open the book across her lap. Its Introduction immediately proclaims: A Deaf Child Must Learn To Speak! Rose stares at the words. She turns the page again. Chapt One: The Elements Classified, starting with: Mouth Cavity this above a lurid illustration of a splayed-open mouth, looks as if it were screaming. The anatomical parts are a clinically labeled in white darts.

Rose tears the lurid page from the big black book like sh tore out the page from the movie magazine in the drug sto fast. She slams the book shut and looks off into space. Upset, she cracks open her bedroom door and looks down be

Downstairs, PEARL, the maid, a young attractive woman wit short stylish bob, enters from the kitchen. She is carryi large silver tray bearing a tea service into the living r She sets it down on a central table in front of where Doc Kincaid sits. The BUTLER stands by his side, awaiting ord When the Maid starts to go, Doctor Kincaid signals her ba appearing to give her further instructions while checking watch, unaware Rose is watching from above.
Rose slowly closes her door and retreats back into her ro
Blinds are being pulled, letting hot morning light rush i machine beeps. Ben’s eyes, squinting open. Blinking at the blurry light. Slowly remembering where he is.  37 38 39 40 WONDERSTRUCK 24.
Through the glass, shifting focus, the bus station across street comes slowly into view. The sign reads: Duluth Station
Ben sees the bus station outside. He gets an idea.

It’s morning, and MUSIC marks the arrival of new paper skyscrapers, perched on Rose’s desk. She has made them fr various screaming-talking-mouth pictures from the big bla book. The result are several silent screaming buildings a to her miniature skyline. Asleep at her desk amidst the scraps and scissors, Rose’s eyes suddenly twitch - a vibration felt from downstairs - she blinks herself awake. INT. ROSE’S HOUSE - DINING ROOM - LATER - 1927 - DAY 40 Rose sits alone with her father at the breakfast table, trying to avoid his gaze. Her father glares at her suspiciously between bites of eg and sausage while attempting to read the paper. Rose catches one of his steely looks and turns away, star into her breakfast plate. He waves his hand in front of h and points to the salt. She passes it. His eyes linger, staring. He salts his eggs and straightens the paper with a mighty shake. He turns the page of his newspaper. An article has been cut out of the center of the last pag and Doctor Kincaid glares through the telltale hole at th guilty face of his daughter. He lowers the paper and starts yelling (though we don’t h him), unleashing far more than the minor infraction deser  4l 42 43 44 WONDERSTRUCK 25.

Rose! For god’s sake I can’t take it any more! You cut everything to shreds! Everything! Go to your room! Now! (he points upstairs) Go! INT. (signing to old woman): He doesn’t know sign.
You can hear? The Old Man nods.
Yes.
But she’s deaf?
Yes. The Old Man nods again. He translates this into sign for old woman. Ben, still making sense of his sudden companio takes a step toward them, gingerly.
I had an accident recently. That's why I can’t hear. The Old Man translates this to the Old Woman.
You scared us! The Old Man holds up a finger to the boy, grabs a pad and from his desk, and starts writing. Ben continues slowly down the stairs as the Old Man holds his message: Can we help you?
(then, to Ben, enunciating his words) Are you okay? Ben understands and nods.

Yeah, thanks. I’m sorry I just... fell asleep for a second.  WONDERSTRUCK 76. He goes to collect his fallen belongings and put them bac into his satchel. The Old Woman kneels down to help Ben collect his things. picks up an old book that had fallen out, and turns it ov revealing Ben’s copy of WONDERSTRUCK. She stops, staring at the cover of her book, then tilts i the direction of the Old Man. He stiffens when he sees it turns to look the Old Woman in the eye. Then they both lo at Ben. Ben stops, realizing they are staring at him with the odd expression. In the eyes of the Old Woman he sees confusio and wonderment and sadness, all rolled into one. She glances down again at the drawings and photos that Be had taken from the museum. When she looks back up at Ben, tears have flooded her eyes. She sways, losing balance, a the Old Man grabs ahold of her. She wipes the tears from eyes. To the Old Man:
(in sign language) Do you realize who this boy is?
(in sign language): Is it possible? Can it be true? He helps her to her feet and she steps back, regaining he balance. Overwhelmed. Almost afraid. Then, urgently:

(signing to old man): How did he end up here? How? The old man gestures to indicate: I have no idea! Ben stares back, confused and perplexed. He feels a strangeness in his body he can’t explain. The Old Woman takes the pen and notebook. She writes with trembling fingers and turns the paper towards him so he c read it. It says: Ben? Ben looks at her in shock.

How do you know my name?  WONDERSTRUCK 77. The Old Man translates Ben’s words into sign, but the Old Woman, who can lip read well, stays fixed on Ben. She wri in the notebook: Where is your mother? Ben, unsure how to answer at first, takes out his wallet hands her the article about his mom’s death. She gasps, sharing it with the Old Man. BEN (CONT’D) Did you know her? She hands Ben back the article. The Old Man writes: How did you find us? Ben roots around in his pockets and finds the Kincaid’s b mark. He points to the note on the back, handing it to th Old Woman. Rose looks at the bookmark and reads: Elaine, I’ll wait f you. Love, Danny. Her eyes well with tears, she turns to Walter and shows h BEN (CONT’D) I came here trying to find my father. Do you know him? The Old Man translates for the Woman. BEN (CONT’D) Who are you? How do you know my name? Rose writes a note for Ben: I’m Rose. This is my brother Walter. Rose signs their names. Walter, the Old Man, nods, smiles gently. Ben is confused. BEN (CONT’D) I saw you at the wolf diorama in the museum! Walter signs Ben’s words to Rose.
What is going on? Tell me! Rose’s face looks sad and complicated. She gets an idea.  126 127 WONDERSTRUCK 78.

(in sign language, to Walter) I need to take him to the museum. He deserves to know his story but I can’t tell him here. Walter nods, in agreement. Rose writes a note and stands, showing it to Ben: Come wi me
Where? She reads his lips but signs to Walter instead:
I’1l find you later...

(mouths ) You want me to come with you? Rose reads his lips and shakes her head, heading to the f door. They exchange signs that mean I love you. She gestures for Ben. And Ben follows her out the door, glancing back to Walter at the last moment, confused but undeterred.
SILENCE. She leads him through the crowded streets briskl with a strange urgency.

Ben follows as she leads him to an empty bench and sits, motioning him to join her. There she pulls out the notebo and pen, opens to a clean page - and pauses. Ben stares a the side of her face. Then Rose looks down and starts to write. When Ben glances down at the page, she keeps writing but turns slightly away so he can’t read it yet. A crowd slowly gathers, awaiting the next bus. The bus arrives but Rose keeps writing.  128 129 130 131 WONDERSTRUCK 79.

More crowds. Lonely faces. More buses. Finally, just as another bus approaches, Rose clicks her tears some pages out of her notebook and puts them in her pocket. Then she grabs Ben’s hand, hurrying them onto the bus.

text: SOUND. Ben and Rose are walking by the Unisphere, the gia silver globe from the 1964 World’s Fair. Lightning flashe the distance. They come to a large building and find the entrance. Lettering over the door reads:

The museum is closed today, but Rose reaches into her bag pulls out a key. She puts the key in the door and they en INT. QUEEN’S MUSEUM - LOBBY - 1977 - DAY 130 The lobby is large and cool. Rose leads Ben down a short hallway and into a dark caver space. INT. QUEEN’S MUSEUM - PANORAMA - 1977 - DAY 131 She opens a panel in the wall and presses a few buttons o control panel. Light suddenly floods the room. Ben’s eyes adjust to the light and he gasps. He can’t believe what he’s seeing. The Panorama. A scale model of the five boroughs of New Y City. 895,000 buildings, 10,000 square feet. Ben looks in the miniature city, glimpsing the hand-painted windows an the paper facades glued to the tiny wood buildings. It’s glorious. Rose leads him onto the Panorama.  WONDERSTRUCK 80.

What is this? Where are we? Rose sits on a bench at the edge of the Panorama and indicates Ben should sit too. She takes out her pad and t to the beginning of the story she’d written on the subway She hands it to Ben. As he begins to read, we zoom across the Panorama.

“I need you to be patient with this story and read it slowly. I've worked in the Queens Museum for fifteen years now, but the story I need to tell you begins a long time before that. We come to the tiny Unisphere and the model of the Queens Museum itself on the Panorama...
“When I was a little girl, in 1927, I came to New York for the very first time...” We fly to the model of the American Museum of Natural His on the Panorama.
“It was my brother Walter who finally rescued me. I found him at The Museum of Natural History where he was working...” We continue to fly across the Panorama...

“I begged him to help me, to get me away from our mother and father. I wanted to stay in New York, I wanted to learn things!” We come to a stop in front of the model of a school, a ti wooden structure with a paper facade. Ben continues to read.

“The first thing Walter did was help me find a school for deaf children. I didn’t even know such a thing existed!”  132 133 WONDERSTRUCK 81. [What follows are a SERIES OF FLASHBACKS, using miniature dioramas, all built by hand out of objects from Ben’s lif These dioramas show us how Ben is imagining the scenes th Rose is describing in her notes. First, we find ourselves in a miniature recreation of a school for the deaf. ]
MUSIC. We push into a window of the school and float into all-girl classroom with miniature figures of deaf student learning sign language:

“My parents divorced when I was very young. It was a big scandal back then because my mother was famous...” A miniature figure of Rose sits with two girls, one of wh shares a movie magazine with Lillian Mayhew on the cover. Through the door to the hall, Rose spots the miniature figures of boys coming out of the printing press room, th hands black from typesetting. One handsome boy, (BILL), a little older than Rose hersel is sharing a hand rag with a schoolmate. He smiles at her sweetly, in his rolled-up shirtsleeves. The miniature figure of Rose smiles back.

“It was there at school I met my Bill, who was training to be a printer. We married and before we knew it had a baby boy.” WE SWEEP across the streets of Manhattan. EXT/INT. BILL AND ROSE’S APARTMENT - 1940'S - DAY -(DIORA We glimpse the tiny family as we enter through the miniat window into their apartment

“The times as they were, everyone worried about us raising a hearing child...”  134 135 136 137 WONDERSTRUCK 82. We see the miniature figures of BILL and ROSE, with a bab Rose’s lap, posing for a self-portrait that Bill snaps wi push of a button on the camera. A light flashes.

“,..But our boy managed to handle his lack of deafness just fine...” INT. AMNH - EXHIBITIONS DEPT. - 1950’S - DAY - (DIORAMA) Another miniature memory. We see miniature figures of peo sitting at endless desks working on displays, fossils, models, etc...
“Soon after I had married, Walter helped me get a job at the museum, in the exhibitions department. I'd always loved making models so it suited me well.”
A miniature Rose working on a forest diorama, replete wit wild animals. On the floor, her young son creates a repli of his own.
“I worked there for many years, along side my son.” INT. QUEEN’S MUSEUM - PANORAMA - 1977 - DAY 136 Ben continues to read.
“But soon planning began for the 1964 World’s Fair...” Ben looks up at Rose. She gestures to a TV built into the exhibition, which Ben turns to. On the screen WE SEE:

MUSIC. We see the World’s Fair being built, different pavilions, buildings.  138 139 140 WONDERSTRUCK 83. We see posters advertising it, talking about how it’1l ha rides and exhibitions from around the world. We see flag poles rise, fountains turned on, streets paved.
The camera soaring over the actual city of New York, as B continues reading:

“One of those attractions was going to be the Panorama, a scale model of the entire city of New York, all five boroughs, all 895,000 buildings, the largest architectural model ever built. It was an opportunity I couldn’t pass up so I left the Museum of Natural History to work on the Panorama in Queens.” The AERIAL view of Manhattan dissolves into:
The Panorama. We move across the miniature city.
“Sadly, my Bill had passed away by then. So it was just my son and me.” Now the Panorama turns into:
The Panorama in miniature, being worked on and installed hive of miniature women workers. We finally arrive at the miniature figure of Rose.
“When the World’s Fair ended, the Panorama was so popular they decided to keep it open. But they needed someone to maintain the model, so they hired me for the job.”  141 142 WONDERSTRUCK 84.
We move through a miniature corridor of the museum, lined with tiny filing cabinets, approaching the figure of a ma from behind who stands looking over several of his drawin

“Around that time, our son was appointed the lead designer on a new diorama at the Museum of Natural History, the youngest person to ever have that honor. But you already know this part. The figure of the man turns. He is smiling.
The job would send him up to Gunflint Lake...” Ben stops reading suddenly.

Your son is... Danny? Rose reads his lips. She nods, signing his name, the lett ‘D’ pointed to her heart. Ben realizes what this means. He stares at Rose. BEN (CONT’D) (in wonder) You're my grandmother? Rose reads his lips and nods, instinctively signing the w for grandmother. Tears come to her eyes. BEN (CONT’D) Where is he? I came all the way from Minnesota to find him! Where is he?? Rose gets up and leads Ben out onto the Atlantic Ocean. They carefully walk up towards Manhattan, like giants. They step over the Verrazano Narrows Bridge.  143 WONDERSTRUCK 85. Their feet clear the tiny cables of the bridge. Rose leads Ben up the narrow stretch of the East River, stepping over the Brooklyn Bridge, the Manhattan Bridge a the Williamsburg bridge. Ben looks across the model, like Gulliver in Lilliput. Rose points to the writing pad, indicating he should keep reading. Of course the answer is already in his hands.
Ben looks at the page...
“,..The librarian he'd contacted to help him with his research happened to own a small cabin, and he rented it from her...”
Headlights of a miniature truck (in fact it’s a toy truck from Ben's room) approach Ben’s old street, revealing a figure silhouetted in the door of the house, waving in th headlights.
(From the truck) Miss Wilson? Is that you? Am I at the right place? The miniature figure of Elaine emerges into the light. He hair is in a ponytail. She is young and beautiful.
You are indeed, Mr. Lobel - not an easy feat this time of year. The cabin is right over there. The miniature figure of DANNY (early 30's, handsome), cal out again from the window of his truck.
It’s Danny. LATER, Danny and Elaine are enjoying themselves, skating ice in a miniature recreation of the woods of Minnesota beneath a shimmering sky.
Whoa! I don’t like the ice. I don’t trust it.  144 145 146 147 WONDERSTRUCK 86. Elaine laughs.
Come on, Danny. It’s not gonna break. It’s two feet thick. Don’t you trust me?
(Laughing) I’m not sure right now!
Another evening, the miniature figure of Danny seated at miniature desk as he writes to Rose.
Dear Mom, the research is going well. Very helpful staff, especially this librarian...
Ben looks up to Rose then back down. He continues to read

A miniature of the hallway with the wolf diorama, just as rear painted sky and horizon of the actual diorama is bei carefully slid into position by Danny’s hand. Danny and his crew observe the process with acute attenti taking in the final result: the wolves leaping, the blue snow, the stars, the aurora borealis...

“,..Eventually he completed the diorama of the wolves. I still go visit it whenever I can. It’s the only one he got to make.” INT. ELAINE’S HOME - 1965 - NIGHT -(DIORAMA) 147 The miniature figure of Elaine spots a brown paper packag that’s been left for her on her desk. Inside is a tiny copy of WONDERSTRUCK, She sees the bookm and turns it over: Flaine, I’ll wait for you. Love, Danny  148 149 WONDERSTRUCK 87. INT. QUEEN’S MUSEUM - PANORAMA - 1977 - NIGHT 148 Ben has come to the end of the writing. He turns to Rose, pulls the last few pages from her pocket. She’s been hold on to them. She hands them gently to Ben.

“Your dad was ill Ben, he had a heart condition, the same one his father had. It kept him out of the war. But a few years after he returned from Gunflint Lake, his heart...” Ben looks up at Rose. Night is falling in the Panorama and the fluorescent ligh are coming up again across the city. Ben looks away. Rose takes his hand. He lets her take him her arms and he starts to cry. Soon the lights start to come up across the city. Rose ha been crying too. She points again to the notebook. Ben doesn’t want to kee reading, but Rose insists...
“,..This Panorama is not just a model of New York City. It’s also the story of your father’s life.” Ben looks up at Rose who smiles. She points. Keep reading
The miniature figure of Rose is busy fitting a model of P 176 onto the panorama.

“When I took the job, I thought it would be fun to secretly personalize the Panorama. I hid little mementos from your father’s life inside the buildings...” Just before setting it into place she slips a bitten penc stub beneath the model of the school. Finally, we see the miniature figure of Rose placing anot building onto the panorama and slipping the tiny family p (taken earlier) underneath this one.

Ben and Rose are standing on the East River. Rose leads Ben around the southern tip of Manhattan, step over the bridges again. They head up the other side of th island, along the Hudson River, until they are standing o the blue painted water that separates Manhattan from New Jersey. Rose carefully leans over the Panorama, grips the America Museum of Natural History and pulls upward. There is a li resistance but the entire city block gives way. Rose turns it over and picks out a piece of paper folded ago. She opens it and hands it to Ben. It’s a child’s drawing of two wolves running through the snow. Ben thinks Danny must have drawn it, but then he looks at signature on the drawing and is shocked. It’s signed: Ben. He looks up at Rose.

SOUND. A crowd of miniature figures, dressed in black, is gathering beneath the blue whale - which we might recogni as the same toy whale that had been in Ben’s room earlier We see the miniature figure of Rose, standing with the ot mourners. She turns to see: The miniature figure of Elaine, standing apart from the others, with a miniature figure of 4-year-old BEN at her side, who holds a piece of paper.  154 155 156 WONDERSTRUCK 89.

“I knew everyone at Danny’s funeral except for two people, a woman and a little boy. She introduced herself and I recognized her name from Danny’s letters. She told me she'd brought her son earlier and showed him the diorama Danny had made.” The figure of Elaine holds little Ben’s hand. He shows Ro the paper. It’s his drawing of the two wolves in the dior

I don’t remember any of this... Ben and Rose look out across the Panorama. In the distanc hear something that Ben and Rose can not: THUNDER. But something else catches Rose’s attention. A slight vibration. She pauses. We see the tiny flags on the model of the Queens Museum, out on the Panorama, vibrate ever so slightly with each c of thunder.
We look out, over Queens, with Manhattan lit up in the distance, and from somewhere very far away, we hear thund and see distant bolts of lightning moving towards the cit
There is rumbling, a terrible crash that Ben and Rose don flinch at. But there’s something strange that Rose is aware of.

...that’s why I dreamed of them, the wolves... I saw them! Rose looks at Ben, reminding him she can’t understand him he’s facing away from her. She points to the paper. She w him to write it.  157 WONDERSTRUCK 90. Ben starts to write, a smile on his face... Then, another much louder crash of thunder, the lights flicker for a moment. The flags on the model of the Queens museum vibrate again Then...

text: We watch as lightning hits the city and sections of New Y flicker off, the lighting grid going black, until the ent city is without power, and it stands in silhouette agains the night sky.
The miniature city is plunged into darkness as well. We h breathing and unsteady footsteps and gasps. We hear the s of the pen dropping. After a few tense moments...

(yelling) Hello? What happened? Help! Rose makes a strangled sound that might be the word “come but it’s hard to tell... In the dimmest dark we spot Rose taking a step toward Ben grabbing his hand. More breathing. The Panorama creaks beneath their feet. After several more tense moments: A flash of light with a brief bursting sound. SILENCE. In the brief illumination, we see Rose and Ben holding ea other, terrified. A few more seconds of blackness then - Another flash of light with a noise: we see Ben turn his towards the exit of the Panorama.

Blackness Another flash with a noise: Ben is leading Rose slowly do the Hudson River.  158 159 160 161 WONDERSTRUCK 91. Blackness Another flash with a noise: Ben is stepping over a bridge Blackness Another flash with a noise: They exit the Panorama.

SILENCE. They are heading towards the door... Blackness. But a figure now seems to be visible outside t door up ahead. Another flash with a noise: But this time we see the sour of the light. It’s Jamie, holding his Polaroid camera. There are photos his feet. He is relieved to finally spot Ben and Rose.
When Rose opens the door: SOUND. The noises of cars, honking. They stand outside the door. Ben is shocked to see Jamie.
Jamie? How did you get here?
I followed you!

Ben, has just left the secret room with his satchel. Jami has grabbed his camera and starts to follow him out. FLASHBACK - EXT. KINCAID’S BOOKS - 1977 - DAY 160 Ben has entered Kincaid’s, and then we move aside slightl reveal Jamie looking on from across the street.
Ben and Rose walk up the steps and enter the museum’s fro door. Jamie looks on, peeking out from behind a tree.  162 163 WONDERSTRUCK 92.
All the streetlights in the parking lot are dark. The onl light outside is the moon. Strange distant sounds. Breaki glass. Ben is trying to lip-read what Jamie is saying...
Wait. I don’t understand!
What?
She’s the lady from... A screech of brakes from somewhere far off and Jamie turn

From an adjoining street a van is screeching crazily alon dark empty block. We can hear the radio from inside the v (and just make out the name painted on the side: Klein Gu Service) in the middle of a report about the blackout. Th van careens out of sight, followed by the rise of an approaching police siren. Rose instinctively pulls the boy closer to the door of th museum. Then she gets an idea. She brings the boys back inside the museum and locks the door behind her. But we remain outside, watching as they vanish into the d building. We begin to float upwards, coasting along the side of the museum, a movement that feels as if we’re caught on a gen breeze. The steadiness of the movement, however, is in contrast t the sounds we hear, the indications of violence and dange somewhere in the darkness. But as we continue our ascent up the side of the building the sounds begin to diminish. We find ourselves at the roof of the museum with the roun skeleton of the Unisphere silhouetted against the night s Trees shake. We travel onwards, across the roof now, past the ducts an air vents and flag poles, the debris gathered along the gutter of the roof. The sounds are almost all gone now.  WONDERSTRUCK 93. And finally, we reach our destination. We've caught up with Rose, Ben and Jamie, who have come t the roof for refuge. They are standing in the gutter, looking down over a low wall. Rose squeezes Ben’s arm, then she points to Jamie, wantin know who he is. Unnoticed by Rose are more sounds in the background. A cr a shout. Rose repeats herself, signing: Who is this? Ben looks at Jamie, who looks back at him. A kind of understanding passes between them. Ben touches his palm to his chest (indicating: my) then raises his right hand and begins to fingerspell:
Jamie's eyes shift from Ben’s hand to his face. He mouths reply in silence, affirming what Ben has finger-spelled:

Friend. Rose takes Ben’s hand. He looks up at her with love. He t to Jamie, with the same dazzled look, and takes Jamie’s h Their faces, lit by moonlight, shine with surprise. They turn to the unlit skyline of Manhattan: quiet, dark, mysterious. Above it, hovering in the sky, a canopy of stars as clear bright as any in Gunflint Lake. The big dipper shines lik diamonds vaulting through the night. At this distance, in the strange silence, the city has be a place of peace. And at this moment the three of them are happy, looking a the stars. Jamie points up. Ben and Rose look. A meteor blazes across the sky.
